short_summary: Explores the impact of spaceflight on human health at the molecular level, focusing on the nuclear factor kappa-light-chain-enhancer of activated B cells (NF-κB) pathway. Studies show negative health impacts in various cell types.

title: Interplay of space radiation and microgravity in DNA damage and DNA damage response
authors: María Moreno-Villanueva, Michael Wong, Tao Lu, Ye Zhang, Honglu Wu
short_summary: Examines the impact of space radiation and microgravity on DNA damage in living organisms, discussing potential risks for adverse health effects such as cancer. Concludes that more experiments are needed in space to address synergies between these factors and cellular repair processes.

title: Synergistic Effects of Weightlessness, Isoproterenol, and Radiation on DNA Damage Response and Cytokine Production in Immune Cells
authors: Maria Moreno-Villanueva, Alan H. Feiveson, Stephanie Krieger, AnneMarie Kay Brinda, Gudrun von Scheven, Alexander Bürkle, Brian Crucian, Honglu Wu
short_summary: This study investigates the synergistic effects of isoproterenol, radiation, and microgravity on DNA damage response and cytokine production in immune cells using RWVs. Significant synergistic effects on ADRB2 gene expression were observed, with radiation increasing ADRB2 expression and microgravity causing more DNA strand breaks. Cytokine production was induced by radiation only in microgravity, and isoproterenol prevented most of the microgravity-mediated effects.

title: Transcriptome and proteome responses in RNAlater preserved tissue of
authors: Colin P. S. Kruse, Proma Basu, Darron R. Luesse, Sarah E. Wyatt
short_summary: Investigates the effectiveness of RNAlater in preserving both RNA and proteins in plants, serving as a feasible alternative to snap-freezing in liquid nitrogen when that is not practical.

title: Spaceflight induces novel regulatory responses in Arabidopsis seedling as revealed by combined proteomic and transcriptomic analyses
authors: Colin P. S. Kruse, Alexander D. Meyers, Proma Basu, Sarahann Hutchinson, Darron R. Luesse, Sarah E. Wyatt
short_summary: The study explores changes in Arabidopsis seedlings' gene expression and protein abundance under microgravity conditions, revealing impacts on post-transcriptional regulation, cell wall synthesis, redox/microtubule dynamics, and plastid gene transcription. Potential to enhance cytoskeletal organization, cell wall composition, biomass production, and growth in microgravity.

title: Microbial applications for sustainable space exploration beyond low Earth orbit
authors: Allison P. Koehle, Stephanie L. Brumwell, Emily P. Seto, Anne M. Lynch, Camilla Urbaniak
short_summary: Research highlights the role of microbes in promoting self-sufficiency and sustainability, as well as potential risks to astronaut health and spacecraft, during long-duration missions beyond Low Earth Orbit.

title: Toward sustainable space exploration: a roadmap for harnessing the power of microorganisms
authors: Rosa Santomartino, Nils J. H. Averesch, Marufa Bhuiyan, Charles S. Cockell, Jesse Colangelo, Yosephine Gumulya, Benjamin Lehner, Ivanna Lopez-Ayala, Sean McMahon, Anurup Mohanty, Sergio R. Santa Maria, Camilla Urbaniak, Rik Volger, Jiseon Yang, Luis Zea
short_summary: Proposing microbial biotechnologies for sustainable space exploration, addressing resource independence and ethical considerations, with potential Earth applications.

title: Longitudinal characterization of multispecies microbial populations recovered from spaceflight potable water
authors: Jiseon Yang, Jennifer Barrila, C. Mark Ott, Olivia King, Rebekah Bruce, Robert J. C. McLean, Cheryl A. Nickerson
short_summary: Research on ISS potable water microbiota reveals temporal dependence, suggesting microbial adaptation over time, with implications for space and terrestrial life-support systems.

title: Designing a Novel Monitoring Approach for the Effects of Space Travel on Astronauts’ Health
authors: Anurag Sakharkar, Jian Yang
short_summary: This study aimed to develop a health monitoring approach for astronauts in space, identifying 218 differentially expressed genes and a shortlist of 32 genes that could be used to monitor astronauts' health during space travel.

title: Draft genome sequence of
authors: Sara Koroli, Kristina Buss, Joy M. Blain, Gautam Sai Nakka, Mina Hong, Robert JC McLean, Caroline M. Plugge, Jiseon Yang
short_summary: Report of the draft genome sequence for a Sphingomonadaceae species from studies on long-term genetic changes in drinking water biofilm species.

title: Overexpression of CupB5 activates alginate overproduction in
authors: Anna K. de Regt, Yeshi Yin, T. Ryan Withers, Xin Wang, Tania A. Baker, Robert T. Sauer, Hongwei D. Yu
short_summary: The research aims to understand how overexpression of CupB5 gene affects alginate production in microorganisms, potentially advancing biotechnological applications.

title: Burn Injury-Associated MHCII
authors: Walter E. Cromer, Scott D. Zawieja, Karen M. Doersch, Hayden Stagg, Felicia Hunter, Binu Tharakan, Ed Childs, David C. Zawieja
short_summary: Research investigated the effect of burn injury on immune cell populations and lymphatic endothelial permeability in a rat model, finding an increase in MHCII.

title: Future space experiment platforms for astrobiology and astrochemistry research
authors: Andreas Elsaesser, David J. Burr, Paul Mabey, Riccardo Giovanni Urso, Daniela Billi, Charles Cockell, Hervé Cottin, Adrienne Kish, Natalie Leys, Jack J. W. A. van Loon, Eva Mateo-Marti, Christine Moissl-Eichinger, Silvano Onofri, Richard C. Quinn, Elke Rabbow, Petra Rettberg, Rosa de la Torre Noetzel, Klaus Slenzka, Antonio J. Ricco, Jean-Pierre de Vera, Frances Westall
short_summary: The ISS serves as a long-lasting research platform for space experiments in astrobiology and astrochemistry, providing valuable scientific data over two decades.

title: The smallest space miners: principles of space biomining
authors: Rosa Santomartino, Luis Zea, Charles S. Cockell
short_summary: Research investigates potential use of microorganisms for in-situ resource utilization on Moon, Mars, and asteroids. Differences between terrestrial and extraterrestrial conditions require specific methods research.

title: The smallest space miners: principles of space biomining
authors: Rosa Santomartino, Luis Zea, Charles S. Cockell
short_summary: Research explores the use of microorganisms for mining minerals, water, and volatiles on the Moon, Mars, and asteroids as a means to achieve independence from terrestrial resources. Challenges posed by space conditions require specific research into organotrophic and community-based bioleaching mechanisms.

title: Simulated Micro-, Lunar, and Martian Gravities on Earth—Effects on
authors: Lily A. Allen, Amir H. Kalani, Frederico Estante, Aaron J. Rosengren, Louis Stodieck, David Klaus, Luis Zea
short_summary: Studying bacterial growth, changes and antibiotic sensitivity under simulated lunar and Martian gravities using inclined clinostats.

title: Biofilm formation of
authors: Pamela Flores, Samantha A. McBride, Jonathan M. Galazka, Kripa K. Varanasi, Luis Zea
short_summary: Investigates bacterial biofilm behavior in microgravity to mitigate risks for spacecraft systems and astronaut health.

title: Competitive Growth Assay of Mutagenized
authors: Junya Zhang, Bárbara S. F. Müller, Kevin N. Tyre, Hope L. Hersh, Fang Bai, Ying Hu, Marcio F. R. Resende, Bala Rathinasabapathi, A. Mark Settles
short_summary: Investigating the growth of microalgae in breathable plastic tissue culture bags for potential use in space-based photosynthetic production systems.

title: Spatial Characterization of Microbial Communities on Multi-Species Leafy Greens Grown Simultaneously in the Vegetable Production Systems on the International Space Station
authors: Mary E. Hummerick, Christina L. M. Khodadad, Anirudha R. Dixit, Lashelle E. Spencer, Gretchen J. Maldonado-Vasquez, Jennifer L. Gooden, Cory J. Spern, Jason A. Fischer, Nicole Dufour, Raymond M. Wheeler, Matthew W. Romeyn, Trent M. Smith, Gioia D. Massa, Ye Zhang
short_summary: Investigated microbial communities on multi-species leafy greens grown simultaneously in the Veggie units on ISS, aiming to establish sustainable crop production for long-term deep space missions.

title: Response of
authors: Ye Zhang, Jeffrey T. Richards, Alan H. Feiveson, Stephanie E. Richards, Srujana Neelam, Thomas W. Dreschel, Ianik Plante, Megumi Hada, Honglu Wu, Gioia D. Massa, Grace L. Douglas, Howard G. Levine
short_summary: This study evaluated the impact of simulated solar particle event protons and galactic cosmic rays on dry and hydrated seeds of a model plant, investigating potential risks for long-term lunar and Mars missions involving crop production.

title: Editorial: Revisiting the limits of plant life - plant adaptations to extreme terrestrial environments relating to astrobiology and space biology
authors: Agata K. Zupanska, Carmen Arena, Gustavo E. Zuñiga, Angelica Casanova-Katny, Johanna D. Turnbull, León A. Bravo, Patricio Ramos, Hang Sun, Vladimir V. Shishov
short_summary: Explores plant adaptations to extreme terrestrial environments in relation to astrobiology and space biology.

title: Metagenomic interrogation of urban Superfund site reveals antimicrobial resistance reservoir and bioremediation potential
authors: Sergios-Orestis Kolokotronis, Chandrima Bhattacharya, Rupobrata Panja, Ian Quate, Matthew Seibert, Ellen Jorgensen, Christopher E Mason, Elizabeth M Hénaff
short_summary: Investigation of Gowanus Canal microbiome reveals potential for bioremediation, heavy metal mitigation, and antimicrobial resistance mapping.

authors: Bryan G. Schellberg, Abigail N. Koppes, Ryan A. Koppes
short_summary: Researchers developed a non-invasive, fiber optic-based sensing platform for monitoring barrier function in a gut-on-a-chip, potentially advancing space biomedical research.

title: 37-Day microgravity exposure in 16-Week female C57BL/6J mice is associated with bone loss specific to weight-bearing skeletal sites
authors: Rukmani Cahill, Elizabeth A. Blaber, Cassandra M. Juran, Margareth Cheng-Campbell, Joshua S. Alwood, Yasaman Shirazi-Fard, Eduardo A. C. Almeida
short_summary: 37-day microgravity exposure in mice during the NASA Rodent Research-1 mission led to site-specific bone loss, particularly in weight-bearing regions of the femur. The study suggests that microgravity unloading might be the primary cause of this bone loss, with space radiation and other systemic stresses having minimal contribution.

title: Effects of Space Flight on Inflammasome Activation in the Brain of Mice
authors: Upal Roy, Roey Hadad, Angel A. Rodriguez, Alen Saju, Deepa Roy, Mario Gil, Robert W. Keane, Ryan T. Scott, Xiao W. Mao, Juan Pablo de Rivero Vaccari
mission: NASA's Rodent Research 1 Mission on SpaceX-4 CRS-4 Dragon cargo spacecraft
short_summary: The study found that spaceflight led to decreased inflammasome activation in the brains of mice during a 37-day ISS mission compared to ground control and baseline groups.

title: Immunization induces inflammation in the mouse heart during spaceflight
authors: Alicia L. Veliz, Lorelei Hughes, Delia Carrillo, Michael J. Pecaut, Mary Kearns-Jonker
short_summary: This study explores heightened inflammation in the heart of mice immunized on the ISS, triggered by the NF-κB signaling pathway and cytokine release.

title: Analyzing the relationship between gene expression and phenotype in space-flown mice using a causal inference machine learning ensemble
authors: James A. Casaletto, Ryan T. Scott, Makenna Myrick, Graham Mackintosh, Hamed Chok, Amanda Saravia-Butler, Adrienne Hoarfrost, Jonathan M. Galazka, Lauren M. Sanders, Sylvain V. Costes
short_summary: The study uses a machine learning ensemble to identify genes linked with liver dysfunction observed in space-flown mice, findings which were not predicted by traditional differential gene expression analyses.

title: Sex-specific cardiovascular adaptations to simulated microgravity in Sprague-Dawley rats
authors: Ebrahim Elsangeedy, Dina N. Yamaleyeva, Nicholas P. Edenhoffer, Allyson Deak, Anna Soloshenko, Jonathan Ray, Xuming Sun, Omar H. Shaltout, Nildris Cruz-Diaz, Brian Westwood, Daniel Kim-Shapiro, Debra I. Diz, Shay Soker, Victor M. Pulgar, April Ronca, Jeffrey S. Willey, Liliya M. Yamaleyeva
short_summary: Study investigates sex-specific cardiovascular adaptations to simulated microgravity in mature rats, finding increased aortic stiffness in female rats after hindlimb unloading.

title: NASA open science data repository: open science for life in space
authors: Samrawit G Gebre, Ryan T Scott, Amanda M Saravia-Butler, Danielle K Lopez, Lauren M Sanders, Sylvain V Costes
short_summary: The repository enhances access to various life sciences, biomedical-clinical, mission telemetry, and omics data, fostering global collaboration to advance understanding of spaceflight's impact on biological systems for future deep space missions.

title: Artificial Gravity Attenuates the Transcriptomic Response to Spaceflight in the Optic Nerve and Retina
authors: Isaac Kremsky, Reyna Pergerson, Stephen Justinen, Seta Stanbouly, Jeffrey Willey, Charles A. Fuller, Satoru Takahashi, Martha Hotz Vitaterna, Mary Bouxsein, Xiaowen Mao
short_summary: Artificial gravity mitigates the harmful effects of microgravity on mouse optic nerve and retina by reducing transcriptomic changes associated with oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and lipid metabolic stress.

title: Effect of Simulated Cosmic Radiation on Cytomegalovirus Reactivation and Lytic Replication
authors: Satish K. Mehta, Douglass M. Diak, Sara Bustos-Lopez, Mayra Nelman-Gonzalez, Xi Chen, Ianik Plante, Stephen J. Stray, Ritesh Tandon, Brian E. Crucian
short_summary: Investigated the effect of simulated galactic cosmic radiation on cytomegalovirus reactivation and lytic replication, suggesting potential risks for astronauts during space missions.

title: Protein kinase 2 of the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89 regulates mitochondrial morphology and function
authors: Yohei Matsunaga, Hiroshi Qadota, Nasab Ghazal, Leila Lesanpezeshki, Till Dorendorf, Jasmine C. Moody, Arnaud Ahier, Courtney J. Matheny, Siva A. Vanapalli, Steven Zuryn, Olga Mayans, Jennifer Q. Kwong, Guy M. Benian
short_summary: Study on UNC-89, a giant sarcomeric protein, reveals that its protein kinase domain PK2 is catalytically active and plays a role in regulating mitochondrial morphology and function. The study suggests potential signaling from sarcomeres to mitochondria.

title: Author Correction: To boldly go where no microRNAs have gone before: spaceflight impact on risk for small-for-gestational-age infants
authors: Giada Corti, JangKeun Kim, Francisco J. Enguita, Joseph W. Guarnieri, Lawrence I. Grossman, Sylvain V. Costes, Matias Fuentealba, Ryan T. Scott, Andrea Magrini, Lauren M. Sanders, Kanhaiya Singh, Chandan K. Sen, Cassandra M. Juran, Amber M. Paul, David Furman, Jean Calleja-Agius, Christopher E. Mason, Diego Galeano, Massimo Bottini, Afshin Beheshti
short_summary: This study investigates the impact of spaceflight on the risk of small-for-gestational-age infants, but specific details about a mission are not provided.

title: Adaptation to space conditions of novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station revealed by functional gene annotations and comparative genome analysis
authors: Lukasz M. Szydlowski, Alper A. Bulbul, Anna C. Simpson, Deniz E. Kaya, Nitin K. Singh, Ugur O. Sezerman, Paweł P. Łabaj, Tomasz Kosciolek, Kasthuri Venkateswaran
short_summary: Study reveals adaptations of five novel bacterial species isolated from ISS to life in space, including hypoosmotic stress management, increased DNA repair activity, and potential pathogenic traits.

title: Celebrating 30 years of access to NASA Space Life Sciences data
authors: Lauren M Sanders, Danielle K Lopez, Alan E Wood, Ryan T Scott, Samrawit G Gebre, Amanda M Saravia-Butler, Sylvain V Costes
mission: Multiple (Skylab, Space Shuttle Program, NASA Balloon Program, ISS)
short_summary: Celebrating 30 years of enhancing our ability to safely explore the cosmos by generating priceless data on life in space, made available through various data repositories including NASA Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) and NASA GeneLab.

title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station
authors: Nicholas Nastasi, Ashleigh Bope, Marit E. Meyer, John M. Horack, Karen C. Dannemiller
short_summary: Study investigates how varying moisture conditions impact microbiome of ISS dust, demonstrating rapid growth and composition changes, with potential for predictive models in spacecraft environments.

title: Spaceflight alters host-gut microbiota interactions
authors: E. Gonzalez, M. D. Lee, B. T. Tierney, N. Lipieta, P. Flores, M. Mishra, L. Beckett, A. Finkelstein, A. Mo, P. Walton, F. Karouia, R. Barker, R. J. Jansen, S. J. Green, S. Weging, J. Kelliher, N. K. Singh, D. Bezdan, J. Galazska, N. J. B. Brereton
short_summary: Spaceflight alters host-gut microbiota interactions, with significant changes observed in 44 microbiome species including reductions in bile acid and butyrate metabolising bacteria.

title: Discoveries from human stem cell research in space that are relevant to advancing cellular therapies on Earth
authors: Fay Ghani, Abba C. Zubair
short_summary: Space-based cell biology research reveals insights into human stem cell properties and behavior, potentially advancing cellular therapies on Earth, highlighting both opportunities and limitations in stem cell applications.

title: Simulated microgravity impairs human NK cell cytotoxic activity against space radiation-relevant leukemic cells
authors: Bradford M. Kuhlman, Jonathan H. Diaz, Trang Simon, Kimberly D. Reeves, Stephen J. Walker, Anthony Atala, Graça Almeida-Porada, Christopher D. Porada
short_summary: Brief exposure to simulated microgravity impairs human NK cell's cytotoxicity against leukemia cells, particularly MOLT-4 (T-ALL), suggesting potential increased risk of leukemogenesis during prolonged space missions.

title: Simulated Microgravity Alters Gene Regulation Linked to Immunity and Cardiovascular Disease
authors: Candice G. T. Tahimic, Sonette Steczina, Aimy Sebastian, Nicholas R. Hum, Metadel Abegaz, Masahiro Terada, Maria Cimini, David A. Goukassian, Ann-Sofie Schreurs, Tana M. Hoban-Higgins, Charles A. Fuller, Gabriela G. Loots, Ruth K. Globus, Yasaman Shirazi-Fard
short_summary: Exposure to simulated microgravity for up to 90 days in rats leads to sex-dependent changes in oxidative damage markers and gene expression associated with immune response and cardiovascular disease progression.

title: Spaceflight increases sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca
authors: Jessica L. Braun, Val A. Fajardo
short_summary: Spaceflight increases sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca, contributing to skeletal muscle atrophy and weakness.
